page.content:
Across the Content Areas

This online information brief, The Power of Strategy Instruction, by the National Dissemination Center (2006), covers the many varieties of strategy instruction and includes links to additional resources.

Did your program participate in the Learning to Achieve project conducted by the national Literacy Information and Communication System (LINCS)? Both this project and the Bridges to Practice project that came before it taught the field a great deal about how to design effective programs and instruction for adults with learning disabilities. Strategy instruction is one of the most effective instructional approaches for adults with learning disabilities. Chapter 3, Explicit Instruction for Strategy Learning, from the Learning to Achieve PD Guidebook, lays out the framework and instructional sequencing for strategy instruction, with many helpful phrases and teacher "moves." In every level from supported to independent, it reminds teachers to sequence instruction through the "I do, We do, You do" phases of gradual release of responsibility.

Writing

Learn more about the concept of strategy instruction, its research base, various approaches, and ideas for applications in the classroom from this TEAL Center Fact Sheet on Self-Regulated Strategy Development which forms the framework for the course. Bookmark this Fact Sheet for future reference and share with colleagues. It may also be downloaded from the TEAL Web site, http://lincs.ed.gov/programs/teal.

Math

  • The report, Building on Foundations for Success: Guidelines for Improving Adult Mathematics Instruction, provides guidance on how instructors can help students reach mathematical proficiency.  Below is an excerpt related to what level of competency learners should acquire for daily life and successful transitions to, and experiences in, college and careers.

Instructional Strategies Guidelines Discussion, pp.27-38: http://lincs.ed.gov/publications/pdf/AdultNumeracyReportFinal2011.pdf

  • The following guide, produced by the Institute of Education Sciences, provides evidenced-based recommendations on how instructors can assist students to improve problem solving abilities.  Recommendations include how to develop metacognitive strategies, increase student flexibility in using multiple problem solving approaches, and teaching students to articulate their processes and methods.

 Improving Mathematical Problem Solving in Grades 4 through 8: A Practice Guide: https://ies.ed.gov/ncee/wwc/Docs/PracticeGuide/mps_pg_052212.pdf#page=29

 

  • In the resource below, researcher Lynda Ginsburg* explains effective instructional practices in math, expanding on typical adult education approaches by providing guidance and cautions.

 Designing Instruction with the Components of Numeracy in Mind: http://www.ncsall.net/fileadmin/resources/fob/2008/fob_9a.pdf#page=1

 

  • Accommodating Math Students with Learning Disabilities : http://www.ncsall.net/index.html@id=325.html

*Lynda Ginsburg is a senior researcher and Associate Director at the Center for Mathematics, Science and Computer Education at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey.
